tianchen92 commented on issue #5698: ARROW-6949: [Java] Fix promotable write to handle nullvectors
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/5698#issuecomment-544486588
 
 
   ListVector and BaseRepeatedValueVector are initialized with ZeroVector.INSTANCE, so when invoke  addOrGetVector it checks zero type, I think NullVector shouldn't be the special case (NullVector should just like other non-zero types), this change seems not right? @emkornfield @praveenbingo @pprudhvi 
 
----------------------------------------------------------------
This is an automated message from the Apache Git Service.
To respond to the message, please log on to GitHub and use the
URL above to go to the specific comment.
 
For queries about this service, please contact Infrastructure at:
users@infra.apache.org

pprudhvi commented on issue #5698: ARROW-6949: [Java] Fix promotable write to handle nullvectors
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/5698#issuecomment-544839130
 
 
   @tianchen92 I hit this issue when I'm trying to read a json like [{"a": 0, "b":[]}, {"a":1, "b":[12]}].  After reading the first row 'b' will be a null vector since the child is null. While reading second row, if we promote even for null types, 'b' would be a UnionListVector with element type Union(Null, Int) which doesn't make sense. 
   
   In general, could you explain how null vector is different from zero vector?
   
 
----------------------------------------------------------------
This is an automated message from the Apache Git Service.
To respond to the message, please log on to GitHub and use the
URL above to go to the specific comment.
 
For queries about this service, please contact Infrastructure at:
users@infra.apache.org

tianchen92 commented on issue #5698: ARROW-6949: [Java] Fix promotable write to handle nullvectors
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/5698#issuecomment-544846103
 
 
   > @tianchen92 I hit this issue when I'm trying to read a json like [{"a": 0, "b":[]}, {"a":1, "b":[12]}]. After reading the first row 'b' will be a null vector since the child is null. While reading second row, if we promote even for null types, 'b' would be a UnionListVector with element type Union(Null, Int) which doesn't make sense.
   > 
   > In general, could you explain how null vector is different from zero vector?
   
   Hmm, I didn't consider promote case. NullVector has length which represents a column with some null values (Null is a ArrowType), and ZeroVector is a special case without length which is used for some initial work such as in ListVector the dataVector = ZeroVector.INSTANCE which means its data vector is not specified.
   In this case, List<Null> type is valid as other types I think, and the code below should throw exception because it want to change dataVector type which is not allowed
   >ListVector listVector = ListVector.empty("input", allocator);
       listVector.addOrGetVector(FieldType.nullable(MinorType.NULL.getType()));
       listVector.addOrGetVector(FieldType.nullable(MinorType.VARCHAR.getType()));
   
   However with this PR, the code above is valid.
 
----------------------------------------------------------------
This is an automated message from the Apache Git Service.
To respond to the message, please log on to GitHub and use the

users@infra.apache.org

tianchen92 commented on issue #5698: ARROW-6949: [Java] Fix promotable write to handle nullvectors
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/5698#issuecomment-544846103
 
 
   > @tianchen92 I hit this issue when I'm trying to read a json like [{"a": 0, "b":[]}, {"a":1, "b":[12]}]. After reading the first row 'b' will be a null vector since the child is null. While reading second row, if we promote even for null types, 'b' would be a UnionListVector with element type Union(Null, Int) which doesn't make sense.
   > 
   > In general, could you explain how null vector is different from zero vector?
   
   Hmm, I didn't consider promote case. NullVector has length which represents a column with some null values (Null is a ArrowType), and ZeroVector is a special case without length which is used for some initial work such as in ListVector the dataVector = ZeroVector.INSTANCE which means its data vector is not specified.
   In this case, List'<'Null/'>' type is valid as other types I think, and the code below should throw exception because it want to change dataVector type which is not allowed
   >ListVector listVector = ListVector.empty("input", allocator);
       listVector.addOrGetVector(FieldType.nullable(MinorType.NULL.getType()));
       listVector.addOrGetVector(FieldType.nullable(MinorType.VARCHAR.getType()));
   
   However with this PR, the code above is valid.

   May be we should allow the type to be changed for null type?

tianchen92 commented on issue #5698: ARROW-6949: [Java] Fix promotable write to handle nullvectors
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/5698#issuecomment-545260825
 
 
   My main point is Null is a valid logical type (as the [spec](http://arrow.apache.org/docs/format/Columnar.html) says), so` List<Null>` should be valid, if this is case, this change is not right. But I have no strong insistence on this, if we think Null should be replaceable as Micah said, this change is ok.
 
----------------------------------------------------------------
This is an automated message from the Apache Git Service.
To respond to the message, please log on to GitHub and use the
URL above to go to the specific comment.

users@infra.apache.org

emkornfield commented on issue #5698: ARROW-6949: [Java] Fix promotable write to handle nullvectors
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/5698#issuecomment-545270634
 
 
   Null is a valid value, but generally it is used as a place holder until a real value is present.
   
   I think @pprudhvi needs to provide a unit test to demonstrate the broken case and the fix.  @tianchen92 if you think this breaks behavior in an unexpected way, could you maybe also suggest a test you would like to see pass?
 
----------------------------------------------------------------
This is an automated message from the Apache Git Service.
To respond to the message, please log on to GitHub and use the

For queries about this service, please contact Infrastructure at:
users@infra.apache.org

praveenbingo commented on issue #5698: ARROW-6949: [Java] Fix promotable write to handle nullvectors
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/5698#issuecomment-545278385
 
 
   I think null as a type should be replaceable like Micah suggests, for e.g. a list that is empty in json will be [] - there is no way to derive the type at this point, it will be replaced when we actually encounter a value later on. There after the type cannot be changed and list can be promoted to a union to support another type.
   
   @pprudhvi I think the ask is to provide a unit test, let us work on adding one for the same. 
 
----------------------------------------------------------------
This is an automated message from the Apache Git Service.
